questions.text: Identify the genus of the mosquito, the eggs of which are collected from the water source of a street and subjected to microscopic examination as given in the image below.
questions.explanation:
ANOPHELES

CULEX

AEDES

MANSONOIDES

EGGS
  • Lays singly
  • Boat shaped
  • Lateral floats

Lays in clusters (100-250 in a single cluster)
  • Lays singly
  • Cigar shaped
  • Lays in clusters
  • Star-shaped

LARVAE
  • No siphon tube
  • Rests parallel to water surface
  • Longer siphon tubes
  • Rests at an angle to water surface
  • Shorter siphon tubes
  • Rests at an angle to water surface

HABITAT

Exophilic: outside house

Clean stagnant water

Anopheles known as a sophisticated mosquito

Exophilic: day

Endophilic: night

Dirty polluted water (ponds)

Endophilic: inside house

Artificial Collected water

Exophilic- Aquatic vegetation (Pistia plants)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male from Bihar, India, presents with a 3-month history of intermittent fever, significant weight loss, and enlargement of the spleen and liver. Physical examination reveals darkening of his skin on the face and extremities. He was bitten by the organism given in the image below. What is the disease and the organism?
questions.explanation:
Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL or Kala-azar)By L. donovani
  • Irregular bouts of fever, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, anaemia, and weight loss.
  • Family history is common
  • Darkening of skin on the face, hands, feet, and abdomen.

Cutaneous Leishmaniasis

Cutaneous leishmaniasis aka Oriental sore caused By L.tropica
  • Results in skin lesions, mainly ulcers, on exposed body parts.
  • Leaves lifelong scars

Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis

By L.braziliensis
  • Destroys mucous membranes of the nose, mouth, and throat.
  • It can cause severe facial disfigurement and social stigma.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a parasite. From the options pick a disease that is not transmitted by it.
questions.explanation:
Types of Lice
  • Head louse (Pediculus capitis)
  • Body louse (Pediculus corporis)
  • Pubic or crab louse (Phthirus pubis)

Transmission
  • Direct contact with infested persons.
  • Indirect contact through clothing, bedding, combs, or brushes.
  • Lice can be blown by wind from heavily infested individuals.

Diseases Transmitted
  • Epidemic typhus (caused by Rickettsia prowazekii)
  • Epidemic relapsing fever (caused by Borrelia recurrentis)
  • Trench fever (caused by Rickettsia quintana)
  • Dermatitis due to scratching and secondary infection.

Control Measures
  • Malathion
  • Personal hygiene
  • Mass delousing

Morphology

Small bilaterally compressed, wingless insects covered with backwardly directed bristles.

Diseases transmitted
  • Plague (bubonic)
  • Endemic or murine typhus
  • Chiggerosis
  • Hymenolepis diminuta

Importance in Public Health

Rat fleas are significant vectors of plague and typhus.

Control measures
  • DDT, gamma-HCH, dieldrin, carbaryl, diazinon, or malathion
  • Diethyltoluamide (DEET) and benzyl benzoate
  • Rodent control

questions.text: A 35-year-old hiker presents with sudden onset fever, severe headache, and a macular rash that appeared around the 5th day of illness. On examination, there is generalised lymphadenopathy and an eschar on his abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Causative bacteria

Orienta (Rickettsia) tsutsugamushi

Transmission

Trombiculid mite

Clinical Features:
  • Acute onset with high fever (104°-105°F), chills, severe headache, malaise, and prostration.
  • A macular rash appears around the 5th day of illness.
  • Generalised lymphadenopathy and lymphocytosis are common.
  • The presence of an eschar (punched-out ulcer with a blackened scab) at the site of the mite bite is characteristic.

Diagnostic Test

Weil-Felix reaction (Heterophile antigen-antibody reaction)

Treatment

Tetracycline

Prophylaxis

Impregnating clothes and blankets with miticidal chemicals (e.g., benzyl benzoate) and mite repellents (e.g., diethyltoluamide) on exposed skin surfaces.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe itching, particularly worse at night, and skin lesions on her hands and wrists. On examination, there are follicular lesions and evidence of secondary infection with crusted papules and pustules. She reports that her husband and children also have similar symptoms. Which of the following is used exclusively as a preventive measure against this disease?
questions.explanation:
Causative Agent

Sarcoptes scabiei, an arthropod known as the itch mite.

Transmission

Close contact with an infected person or contaminated clothing and bedding.

Clinical Features

  • Severe itching, especially at night.
  • Follicular lesions, crusted papules, and pustules.
  • It commonly affects hands, wrists, elbows, axillae, buttocks, lower abdomen, feet, and genitals.

Diagnosis
  • Itching worse at night is a key symptom.
  • Examination reveals characteristic lesions.
  • Confirmation by identifying mites or eggs in skin scrapings.

Treatment
  • Benzyl Benzoate- Applied thoroughly to the entire body below the chin, including the soles of feet, and repeated after 12 hours.
  • Gamma-HCH (Lindane)
  • Tetmosol
  • Sulfur Ointment

Preventive Measures

  • Insecticidal Control
    • Effective insecticides: DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion, toxaphene.
  • Environmental Control
    • Fill cracks and crevices near buildings and paths. Reduce wild rodents and dogs.
  • Protection of Workers
    • Wear protective clothing with insect repellents (indalone, diethyltoluamide, benzyl benzoate).
    • Regularly check for and remove ticks during breaks, and after work, remove ticks by painting them with petrol or paraffin and brushing them off.
    • If necessary, extract with forceps, avoiding breaking mouthparts.

questions.text: The image of a fly is given below. Which disease does it transmit?
questions.explanation:
Synonym

Glossina

Location

African continent

Morphology

Resembles houseflies

Yellow/dark brown

Half an inch long

Health impact

Vectors for trypanosomiasis, causing "sleeping sickness”

Control measures

1. DDT and dieldrin

2. Removing vegetation where tsetse flies breed

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is complaining of heart palpitations, nausea, and facial flushing after being bitten by the insect shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Synonyms
  • Cone-nose bugs

Location
  • Mexico, Central America, and South America

Morphology
  • An inch or more in length
  • Adults have wings

Feeding

  • Exclusively on the blood

Habitat
  • Cracks, fissures, and other hiding places in walls, ceilings, and animal habitations

Health impact
  • Transmit Trypanosoma cruzi [a protozoa], the causative agent of Chagas' disease, causes intense itching, nausea, flushed face, and palpitations of the heart.

Control measures
  • Insecticides like HCH or dieldrin

questions.text: Mr. Smith, a 50-year-old farmer from rural Africa, presents with severe itching and a "leopard skin" appearance on his legs. He complains of worsening vision with photophobia and conjunctivitis. Examination reveals papular dermatitis, skin depigmentation, and early signs of corneal scarring. He gives a history of being bitten by a fly given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Synonyms

Simuliidae.

Morphology

Small with short legs and proboscis and large, broad wings

Black in colour.

Health impact

Bloodsucking and causes river blindness (onchocerciasis).

In contrast - loiasis doesn't cause vision loss , it is present in subconjunctival tissues. (Option C)

Control measures

Abate
